pages.title: Week 2 Project - Store Interface with CSS

elements.content:
➔ Practice using CSS by making a graphical interface for a store
➔ Will add a heading, page directory, store item cards, etc.
➔ Covers concepts and styling code that was discussed in the week 2 presentation

[[h3]]Setup Project[[/]]
(This is already done for you if you are following along in Devnetic)
➔ Create a folder in your directory for images which will be used for the store items
➔ Create another html file which will be one of the sites navigation links (it is just a placeholder as the main focus is styling the main page)
➔ Link fonts from google (in your head section) using the following code:

<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com">
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com" crossorigin>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Roboto&display=swap" crossorigin>

[[h3]]Setup Project pt. 2[[/]]
➔ Next, add 4 images to the Devnetic project by right clicking on a file and selecting "Upload File". Then, select "Lesson-Wide"
(You can definitely add more images and items to your shop) The following examples will be a restaurant webpage, so 4 images of seafood were picked
[[h3]]Add a header and Navigation LInks[[/]]

Welcome to ___

Link 1 Link 2 Link 3

[[h3]]Explanation[[/]]
➔ Create a header with a title of your choice in a main heading tag (<h1>)
➔ The header and links should be enclosed in a <div> to apply CSS in the next step
➔ The nav tag is used for navigation links, as most online stores have a directory to other pages
➔ Add navigation links such as “About Us” or “Contact Us,” and you can use the placeholder HTML page as the link
[[h3]]CSS for the Web Page Header[[/]]

[[h3]]Explanation[[/]]
➔ Applies a font to all text within the body tags
➔ Creates a container for the links and spaces the content evenly in a row
➔ Uses the “top” class that was created earlier to apply styles to the header box including centered text, a border with the specified width/color/type,  a background color, text color, and a box shadow
➔ Applies CSS to the links (the nav selector is optional - if removed, the style will apply to all links in the page)
➔ The normal and visited links will appear green (you should pick your own colors) and without underline
➔ When hovered on, the links should appear red/(your choice of color)
[[h3]]Create a Grid of Items[[/]]

Item Name

Item Description
[[h3]]Grid Styling[[/]]
[[h3]]Grid Item Styling[[/]]

[[h3]]Explanation (HTML block)[[/]]
➔ The first <div> will group all list items (more items will be added later)
➔ Add a <div> for your first item, which will consist of an image, a header and a description
➔ Choose an item from your image folder for the first grid item, and give it a corresponding title and description
➔ Note: image dimensions are often relative to window size, but here, it can be set to what fits your viewing window (ex. 240)
[[h3]]Explanation (CSS blocks)[[/]]
➔ Use the first <div> selector to create a centered grid container, and adjust the dimensions of the columns with the grid-template-columns property
➔ Set the width to 100% to let the image take the full size of the grid box
➔ Adjust the various properties of the box with the grid item selector; properties include width, length, background color, border, text color, fonts, etc.
[[h3]]Grid Item Hover Styling[[/]]

[[h3]]Explanation[[/]]
➔ When the grid item is hovered on, the size should increase (adjust your margins and scale accordingly)
➔ Add a box shadow and a transition when hovered over

➔ Within the grid <div>, copy the item <div> to create 3 more image boxes
